awd_titl_txt: Fundamental Study of Ordered MXenes and Their Defects
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: In 2004, a single atomic layer of graphite, called graphene, was isolated and its remarkable properties were characterized. Consequently, interest in two-dimensional, 2D, solids, where the lateral dimensions are much greater than the thickness has exploded. The awarding of the Nobel prize for graphene in 2010 fueled further interest. In general, 2D solids are characterized by very large surface areas. Furthermore, by confining the electrons, viz. the electric charge carriers, to 2D can also result in new physics. The most recent family of 2D solid discovered is called MXenes where M is a transition metal and X is carbon and/or nitrogen. In this project, single layers of select MXenes are being isolated on a substrate and characterized in order to better understand the effects of chemistry, temperature, surface terminations, order, and magnetic fields on electrical transport. These results are being used to better understand how charge flows in MXenes which, in turn, is of vital importance to designing better lithium batteries, supercapacitors, catalysts, and transparent conductive electrodes to name only a few potential applications of this new and exciting family of 2D solids. Graduate students involved in this project obtain international experience through participation in research activities in collaborating laboratories in Europe and Asia. Undergraduate students are involved in research every summer through Drexel University's STAR program (which supports students who completed their first year of studies, have high GPAs and are interested in research). Many of these students subsequently complete graduate degrees. 

TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Quite recently, two new classes of quaternary ordered MAX phases (M',M")n+1AXn, have been discovered: o- and i-MAX for out-of-plane and in-plane order, respectively. The o-MAX phases are ones where one transition metal sandwiches the other. The i-MAX phases are 211 (n = 1) phases in which the M-planes are themselves ordered. With the judicious choice of etchants, neither, or only one, of the two M elements can be etched - together with the A-layers - to yield MXenes with ordered divacancies in the latter case. The overarching scientific goal of the proposed work is to understand, at a fundamental level, the effects of ordering, both of the M layers and point defects, on the magneto-transport and optical properties of single 2D flakes and spincast films made of the same flakes. Some of the questions posed involve the main electron scattering mechanisms in the ordered/disordered MXenes; what factors influence carrier densities; the effect of terminations and their order/disorder on these values; and whether a band gap can be induced in these materials. In terms of impact, MXenes will likely play a critical/enabling role in the "lego" approach to heterojunctions 'simply' as ohmic contacts. Furthermore, and despite their relatively young age, MXenes have already shown great promise as materials in energy storage - both in supercapacitors and ion batteries/capacitors of lithium and beyond - electro-magnetic shielding, water purification and desalination, catalysis, transparent conductive electrodes, reinforcements in polymer composites among many others. This work facilitates choosing the best MXene chemistry for any given application.

por.por_cntn:
In 2011, we placed a special class of machinable layered ceramics - that we discovered in 1996 and called the MAX phases where M is a metal, A is a second metal, X is carbon and/or nitrogen – in hydrofluoric acid, HF, and selectively etched out the A layers, converting the 3D ceramic into 2D MX flakes, which we named MXene to emphasize the loss of A from the MAX phase; the -ene suffix was added to show that, like graphene, we have 2D flakes. As an analogy, imagine a book in which the pages are glued together and then placed in a solution that only dissolves the glue to such an extent that the pages float away in the solution forming a colloid solution. Here, the A layer is the glue and the pages are 2D MXenes. The thickness of each MXene layer is on the atomic scale and ranges from 3-9 atomic layers which renders them extremely thin.

The number of papers and citations on MXenes has roughly doubled every year since we discovered them (Figure 1). MXenes are so popular because of their potential to be used in a variety of applications, from curing cancer and energy storage to electromagnetic shielding. Figure 2 summarizes some of the applications researched. Funded by the NSF, over the last 5 years we made several breakthroughs in the field of MXenes summarized in ~30 papers and 6 patents.

When the A-layers are selectively etched they are replaced by surface terminations typically comprised of oxygen, fluorine, and hydrogen. These terminations determine many of their properties including whether the 2D sheets remain suspended in the solution – form a stable colloid – or sink to the bottom. A stable colloid is important as it helps improve processibility, which is important for scale-up or making composites, among other properties. We found that by simply changing the pH of the colloid we could not only crash the 2D flakes out of solution but also crumple them. Going back to the book analogy, we found that when we render the solutions (acidic or basic) in which the paper sheets are suspended, the paper sheets crumpled and sank to the bottom. We then showed that the crumpling increased MXenes capacity as anodes in Na-ion batteries compared to conventional MXene-filtered films.

Moreover, we discovered that the edges of the MXene flakes are positively charged and that we can selectively cap these edges with negative ions that can prevent oxidation of MXenes, even in aerated water. This is a major breakthrough as it extended the life of MXenes several-fold and removed a major roadblock towards commercialization. Based on our understanding of the processability of MXenes, we made MXene/polymer composites with several different polymer chemistries. These composites were tested in applications like water permeation membranes, solid electrolytes in batteries, etc. A way to functionalize MXenes using click chemistry (Nobel 2022) was also developed. This approach made it possible to make MXene/polymer composites with improved mechanical properties in minutes rather than hours or even days. The processibility findings were further extended to make epoxy/MXene composites, with improved mechanical strengths and water permeability compared to bare epoxies. During MXene-polymer-composite synthesis it was discovered that MXenes treated with a special surfactant render those that are hydrophilic, hydrophobic. This allowed us to synthesize MXene sheets that were uniformly coated with sulfur which showed remarkable performance as a cathode in Li/S batteries.

Based on our understanding of modifying MXenes surface chemistry, we could tune them to improve catalytic performance in several different reactions like hydrogen evolution, water gas phase shift, epoxide ring opening and selective hydrogenation, etc. These studies were done on MXenes synthesized in water. In several applications where MXenes can be of use, even trace water can sometimes be a problem. So, we developed a protocol to synthesize MXenes in polar organic solvents. This opened new avenues for MXene applications like polymer composites, assemblies with quantum dots, etc. Finally, to study the electronic properties of MXene, we explored different chemistries of MXenes using advanced terahertz spectroscopy, which helped us understand the interflake vs. intraflake carrier dynamics. Given the small size of MXene flakes, it is challenging to study the electronic properties of MXenes using conventional lithography techniques. This roadblock is removed due to the development of non-contact measurements using terahertz spectroscopy. Based on our results using terahertz spectroscopy, we utilized MXenes instead of gold to make transparent photodetector electrodes that performed better than more traditional gold electrodes. We also demonstrated use of MXenes as polarizers and created an efficient capping layer in devices working on the principal 2D electron gas.

Throughout this project, understanding of MXene surface chemistry and electronic properties has increased remarkably, allowing us to improve MXenes performance in multitude of applications ranging from batteries and catalysis to transparent electrodes.
